all_paragraphs: Let’s say you are working on a presentation. You prepared a draft pack yesterday and named it as presentation_v0.pptx. Today, you are going to make some changes. In order not to overwrite your work from yesterday, you create a copy of v0 and rename it to presentation_v1.pptx and make changes to this file. Most of us did something similar to this at some point in our life. This is a simple example of (manual) version control.

Using version control systems, we could make this process more elegant. In fact, version control systems provide more functionality than manual versioning. They help us to organise, backup and document our work flow better, and collaborate efficiently with others. As Data Scientists, we should definitely use version control system. In this post, we will learn the basics of Git, a free widely-used open-source version control system.

If you want to follow along with the code in this post (which I encourage so), ensure your computer has Git version 2.23.0 or higher installed. This is because one of the commands we will visit in this post (git restore) was introduced in version 2.23.0. Here’s one way to ensure this:

Let’s open up a terminal window with the following steps: ➡️ Press cmd + space bar ➡️ Type Terminal ➡️ Press enter➡️ Now, type git --version and press enter.◼️ If it shows the version and the version is 2.23.0 or above, you are all good to go to the next section.◼️ If it says something along “command not found” or it shows the version and the version older is than 2.23.0, install or upgrade Git using this guide.

Let’s check if Git Bash is installed with the following steps:➡️Press windows key ➡️ Type Git Bash ◼️ If an app called Git Bash doesn’t come up as shown in the picture above, it means it’s not installed. You can install it from here.◼️ If an app called Git Bash comes up, press Enter to open up a Git Bash window. We can check the Git version installed with the following command:
If it’s 2.23.0 or above, you are all good to go to the next section. Otherwise, update the version with the following one line:
Let’s check if you have set up your user name and email address:
If it returns no output or you would like to update what’s already set up, use the following template to update:

In this example, we first checked current user details, second we updated them and then we checked if the update is reflected. This example is here to illustrate how to set up/update user name and email address. I would recommend to use your full name and professional email address. Git will use this name and email address as author details when you make a commit. We will see an example later in section 3.4.
Before we dive into commands, it may be helpful to understand how git works conceptually and familiarise with a few common terms. The image below shows a basic Git workflow:

💡 Working directory: Current state of the project directory (what you see in a project directory)💡 Staging area: An area where you prepare changes for a commit💡 Local repository: A repository on your computer💡 Remote repository: A repository hosted on the internet or some network, e.g. GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket

In simple terms, when we want to save (a version of) our work, we make a commit (you can consider commits as snapshots or versions). In order to make a commit, we first need to stage the files we edited, created or deleted. This is because when we commit, Git only stores the changes made to the files in the staging area as part of that particular commit. Next, you can think of repository as a storage for all your commits. All the information regarding commits is saved in a .git subdirectory, which is a local repository. Because Git stores information about commits, we can check out any commits in the past. It’s almost like it gives us an ability to travel back in time and inspect the state of the project in the past.

Staging and committing are central to Git workflow. To illustrate the idea of staging and committing, let’s use online shopping as an analogy. When shopping online, you usually add items in your shopping cart. Once you feel ready to place an order, you first view your cart and assess it, you may want remove certain items or add more items to your cart. After making changes and when you feel satisfied with what’s in your cart, you place an order. We can imagine staging area is like a shopping cart and commit is like an order. Staging is like adding an item to your shopping cart whereas making a commit is like placing an order.
Hopefully, you now have an understanding about how Git works to some degree. In the next section, we will learn how to do basic Git operations on your computer.
In this section, commands are accompanied by a brief description when it’s shown for first time in the following format:

I encourage you to follow along on your computer as you read through to get hands-on experience. Whenever you are not sure what a command does, try searching it in explainshell.com, it will explain what the command does.
As the name suggests, we will create a new folder and initialise a repository in the folder:

After initialising a local repository, we can now see that there is a hidden .git subdirectory in the terminal (or Git Bash if you are on Windows). Notice how it’s not visible in Finder? If you are using Windows, you may or may not see the .git subdirectory in File Explorer depending on your setup.
Since we now have a repository, we will add a file and make our first commit:

You may have noticed how we are frequently checking status. This is to understand and monitor what is happening. My tip is to use git status (my most used Git command) regularly especially when you are learning Git.

In the second last line, we also gave a short description to the commit: ‘Add README.md’ . This is referred to as commit messages (technically, it’s the subject line of the message but in this post, message is used to refer to what’s inside the quotation mark). It’s important to keep your commit messages clean and informative. If you need some guidelines, here’re some style tips I picked up over time on how to write a good commit messages:◼️ Start with a capital letter◼️ Don’t put period at the end◼️ Keep the message within 50 characters◼️ Use imperative form to describe what the commit will do◼️ Keep the message concise, descriptive and professional
Here’re some example commit messages that follow this style guide: ✅ Update model hyperparameters✅ Add deep-dive analysis for target
Additional resources for commit message:🔗 Udacity commit style guide🔗 How to Write a Git Commit Message

Your project directory may contain certain files or folders that you don’t necessarily want to track in the repository. .gitignore helps to ignore/not track certain files or folders in the directory. All you have to do is to specify either literal file names: example.pdf or patterns: *.pdf of the files or folders that you want to ignore in a .gitignore file.
Most of the time, it’s very useful to inspect all the changes before you stage. This way you can avoid committing unintended changes and be 100% sure that the actual changes align with your intent.
Let’s now learn how to ignore files and inspect unstaged changes:

In this example, we have included *.pdf in our .gitignore file. As a result, Git will not track any pdf file. After adding *.pdf in .gitignore, example.pdf no longer appears as untracked file when checking status.
Additional resources: 🔗gitignore.io for creating a useful .gitignore file🔗 How to Use a .gitignore File

Using git diff, we can see details on unstaged changes we made. This means you can use this command for inspecting modifications in your working directory before you stage them. If you run it by itself, it will show the details of unstaged changes for all modified files. We can also put multiple file names behind the command too: git diff README.md .gitignore. You may have noticed when we ran git diff .gitignore, it didn't return anything. That’s because it’s a new file and we have nothing to compare against.

Jupyter Notebooks are popular among Data Scientists. Jupyter Notebooks are stored in JSON format. This makes it hard to see differences between Jupyter Notebooks using git diff. nbdime is a useful tool that makes differences more friendly and human-readible.
Additional resources: 🔗Friendly guide on Git diff🔗Useful tool for diffing Jupyter Notebooks: nbdime

In the example above, we created two separate commits instead of one. This is because I want to point out that you don’t always have to commit all the changes in one go. In other words, you shouldn’t just dump all the changes into one commit. Instead, you should evaluate the changes and plan each commit to be for one logical set of changes (it’s up to you to define what that is). Earlier this year, I did a Git course from Udacity. I would give this free course a 10/10, the content and delivery of content was amazing. I highly recommend it to anyone learning Git. From the course, I learned that if your commit message contains the word ‘and’, it’s a sign you should split your commit into multiple commits. So that’s one tip to remember when sizing your commit.
Now let’s learn how to browse commit history and view the files as of specific commits.

Using git log, we can see the history of commits for the repository. Each commit is followed by its hash (think of it as an id for a commit), author details (remember how you had to set it up in section 1) and datetime of its creation. Adding --oneline, we get more succinct summary for commits.

With git checkout <commit_hash>, we can check out our project directory as of specific commits. In other words, we can travel back in time and inspect versions of your files in the past. Of note, when passing on a commit hash, you don’t have to reference the entire 40-character hash. Git is smart enough to figure out the commit if you provide the first few characters of the hash, as long as that partial hash is at least four characters long and unambiguous. I usually use first 6 characters to reference commits, that has worked fine so far.
Additional resources: 🔗 Git Checkout Explained by freeCodeCamp
While learning Git, you may sometimes face a situation where you want to undo what you previously did. We will learn a few useful commands to undo:

Let’s say you have built a decent model and you have committed your code. But a new idea came to your mind and you really want to try it before deployment. git restore gives you peace of mind in trying this new change. If your idea didn’t work out and you want to just restore to how it was as of last commit and undo all unstaged changes, git restore will save you.

In the example above, we have used git reset in two different ways. First, we used it to unstage incomplete.py. Second, using git reset HEAD^ , we wiped out the last wrong commit as if it never existed.
If for some reason, you need to delete a repository, you can do so like below:
As we can see, we no longer have a repository after runningrm -rf .git.
Well done for making it this far. Let’s visualise some of the commands we have visited in this post:

Learning Git for the first time can be challenging, so if you are still a little bit confused about Git, don’t worry, you just need more exposure and practice. I encourage you to practice what we just did and try to apply your knowledge to your real projects.

We only touched on the very basics of Git in this post. As you learn more about Git, you will find out that the commands we visited have more uses with small tweaks and there are multiple ways to accomplish the same thing. Git is much more capable of what we just learned. Once you feel comfortable working on your local computer, you can start looking up other useful functionalities such as how to use remote repository, branching, merging and aliasing common commands. Here’re some additional learning resources:
🔗 The Pro Git Book🔗 The Git Community Book🔗 Version Control with Git by Udacity🔗 GitHub Guides 🔗 GitHub Learning Lab

Thank you for reading my post. I hope you gained useful knowledge about Git. If you are interested, here are links to some of my posts:
